description:
Drosophila kikkawai is a species of fruit fly that belongs to the family Drosophilidae. It is commonly known as the Kikkawa's fruit fly, named after the Japanese entomologist Yoneo Kikkawa, who first described the species in 1938.

Drosophila kikkawai is a small insect, typically measuring between 2 to 3 millimeters in length. It has a characteristic brown or yellowish-brown body with dark wings. The species is known to be widely distributed across Asia, including India, China, Japan, and Southeast Asian countries.

As a member of the Drosophila genus, Drosophila kikkawai shares many of the common traits and behaviors observed in other fruit fly species. It is known to feed on various types of ripe or decaying fruits, and its larvae develop within the fruit's flesh. The species is often used as a model organism in various scientific studies, particularly in the fields of genetics, developmental biology, and evolutionary biology.

Drosophila kikkawai has been the subject of numerous research studies, contributing to our understanding of various biological processes, such as mating behavior, pheromone communication, and genetic diversity within the species. Its relative ease of cultivation and well-characterized genome make it a valuable tool for scientific investigations in the laboratory setting.
